video.title: CSS Tutorial – Full Course for Beginners
video.description:
In this in-depth course, you will learn about all the key features of CSS. This is the most comprehensive CSS course we've published to date. So if you want to become an expert in Cascading Style Sheets, this is the course for you.

✏️ Course from Dave Gray. Check out his channel: http://youtube.com/DaveGrayTeachesCode 

💻 Course Resources: https://github.com/gitdagray/css_course

🎥 Dave's HTML course: https://youtu.be/kUMe1FH4CHE

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
(0:00:00) Intro
(0:01:08) Chapter 1: Start Here
(0:14:50) Chapter 2: Selectors
(0:34:41) Chapter 3: Colors
(0:51:13) Chapter 4: Units & Sizes
(1:11:56) Chapter 5: Box Model
(1:37:08) Chapter 6: Typography
(2:00:29) Chapter 7: Styling Links
(2:16:37) Chapter 8: List Styles
(2:32:31) Chapter 9: Mini Project
(2:45:04) Chapter 10: Display
(3:00:21) Chapter 11: Floats
(3:12:46) Chapter 12: Columns
(3:34:30) Chapter 13: Position
(3:57:53) Chapter 14: Flexbox
(4:21:39) Chapter 15: Grid Layout
(4:46:33) Chapter 16: Images
(5:32:40) Chapter 17: Media Queries
(5:58:59) Chapter 18: Card Project
(6:33:21) Chapter 19: Pseudo
(6:52:56) Chapter 20: Variables
(7:20:28) Chapter 21: Functions
(7:50:05) Chapter 22: Animations
(8:37:33) Chapter 23: Organization
(8:57:23) Chapter 24: Final Project

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Ruleaus
topLevelComment.text: I don't understand in Chapter 7 why those pseudo classes for the links have to be in a particular order to work. The state of the anchor element is independent of the order, so why can't the hover pseudo class work when the mouse hovers over the link regardless of order? It's like the state of the element isn't recognized anymore because of the order in CSS. I'm probably not the only one who's confused by this.

replies.author: Ruleaus
replies.text:
@Angelina Ivanova 
I still don't understand it with the explanation that the last, bottom-most pseudo class overrides the one before it. Maybe it requires an understanding of how the CSS code is read or processed by the browser. Would help to understand what goes on under the hood, because I'm clueless about that. It's good to know the why behind the mnemonic. So, I'll just keep chipping away at it little by little. Thanks for your input :)

replies.author: Angelina Ivanova
replies.text: Okay so I hope you understand this, I'll give my best explanation. The way I see things, you need to have the a:hover after the a:visited since the last written class is the one that will be applied and have more priority compared to others (since CSS stands for cascading style sheets). So basically look at it this way: if you were to write the hover class first which would be applied to a particular element you have chosen, and then you were to write the visited class, then the visited class will override the hover one since it was written last and is the one thing that will not be overriden. On the opposite, if you were to write the visited class first and then the hover, the hover class will have more priority and will not be overriden since it was written last. If you want a more in depth explanation, check out the LoVe&HAte mnemonic (which stands for the order: a:link, a:visited, a:hover, a:active). Hope it helps, I still haven't entirely figured it out myself yet@Ruleaus

replies.author: Ruleaus
replies.text: @Angelina Ivanova yes why does it have to be in a particular order when the element's state is what causes the styling to be applied. For example, the link changes color when it's visited, but that's totally different than the hover state that occurs when the mouse pointer hovers over the link. So I don't get why the a:hover has to be after the a:visited. They're two different states, so why does having a:visited after erase the a:hover state?

replies.author: Angelina Ivanova
replies.text: Do you mean why the a:visited has to be before the a:hover?

topLevelComment.author: Goldie Codes
topLevelComment.text:
Thanks for this tutorial! Side note on a CSS property:
When I first heard about CSS clamp, I struggled to use it effectively in my projects. I searched YouTube videos and blogs to figure out what I was doing wrong. Sadly none of these videos or articles actually pointed out WHAT NOT TO DO to avoid frustration with CSS CLAMP.

Eventually, I figured it out. But this long process wasn't funny to me a single bit, so I took out time to make a very comprehensive video on CSS clamp, demonstrating how to use it to effectively eliminate media queries when declaring font sizes as well as widths. I also point out clearly for you, what you just shouldn't do so you don't spend hours wondering why your CSS clamp isn't working! I just published the video a few days ago. You'd learn a lot from it that will give you freedom and confidence with using clamp.

replies.author: Angelina Ivanova
replies.text: Look for any colon, comma, bracket, etc you might have omitted. If it's not that see if you have accidentally started a CSS comment and have not ended it (this would mean that you have accidentally hidden your entire *{...} inside the comment and none of it will be applied). If this happens to be the case, end the comment so the selector will be visible and applied. If this also doesn't work, you should use the CSS validator that Dave mentioned in the video. I think this would be my last resort 😂😂 other than that you can search the net for a solution. Hope I helped.

topLevelComment.text: Honestly I appreciate you and your content < Technical Analysis is good but I find It truly baffling that major crypto youtubers just look mostly at pure T.A and completely ignore the bigger narrative of why BTC is pumps/pumped and why the future outlook will be even rosier than it seems. We were already on shaky footing with historically low volume and almost pure whale pumps,narrowly avoiding a long-term bear market. More emphasis should be put into day tradiing as it is less affected by the unpredictable nature of the market. I have made over 12 btc from day tradng with Bradley James Holly insights and charts. He been one step ahead of other analysis..

topLevelComment.author: Liquid Flames
topLevelComment.text:
It blows my mind how far HTML and CSS have come. I started teaching myself about web design in the early 90s. Right click> view source. I would spend hours pouring over notepad screens tweaking and modifying other people's HTML. Eventually, I was writing my own from scratch.

Then, one day, I came across one that had the CSS tags in the header. Back then, CSS was just an easy way to change the colors and fonts of every page on a site by changing one file. It made things so much easier.

It still does that but now it does _so much_ more. Browsers are so much more sophisticated than IE and Netscape Navigator 3.

I didn't keep up with it. I stopped learning in the early aughts when I was tinkering with Macromedia Flash and Actionscript. This course is exactly what I've been looking for to get me back up to speed with CSS. I'm bookmarking this video to use as a reference.

replies.author: Steven Coker
replies.text: Me too. I remember the days from 1996 to early aughts when I created websites using only a basic text editor.  I never used CSS back then. Stopped working with html sites 20ish years ago and am relearning now to get a defunct site back online. This time I will be using CSS.

replies.text: You couldn't read any CSS book, could you?
